ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was excellent in helping me improve my oral skills as well as my general comfort with the French language. From last semester to this semester, I can see an improvement in my ability to understand French and communicate to native French speakers. I really liked using books and movies to learn French as opposed to French In Action.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The oral portion isn't conducive to people who require a little more time to hear. Also on the final exam, in any other normal context you could use a dictionary or look up the conjugation of a word before writing something in french, so on the essay portion, we should be allowed to do that.

Though it seems annoying at first, the daily class is incredibly useful in whipping all of the students into shape. Professor Turcat was kind and gentle, but also intent on teaching us the mechanics of French. 

As for weaknesses, I think there *could* be a system of checking the homework, since I feel like I fell off when I would occasionally drop assignments and there was no punishment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this class, especially with Professor Turcat. I think he cared a lot about the class and wasn't too clinical in his teaching.
